title.narrative: SP Lobby & Advocacy International - restoring the social contract

description.narrative: A stable, peaceful and equitable society in fragile countries in which: Local women and women’s organizations and youth and youth organizations are able to influence and meaningfully participate in decision-making processes, specifically those related to peacebuilding; Security and justice provision is people-centered and security and justice institutions are effective, inclusive and accountable; A resilient health system is in place, contributing to Universal Health Coverage; A sustainable, diversified economy benefits local communities
Communities in fragile contexts.

High level international dialogue, like on SDG16+, and peace negotiations around armed conflicts define the frameworks for national policies in the six programme countries of the strategic partnership: Afghanistan, Burundi, CAR, DRC, Nigeria and South Sudan. Under international pressure the tendency of shrinking civic space can be countered. For these reasons, it is necessary for the programme partners, including local partners, to take part in international dialogue processes.

comment.narrative: (Engendered Peace - YPS): Through the global coalition of youth, peace and security, which connects youth organizations, UN and INGOs together. UNOY is a co-chair, Cordaid is a a menber. Also Cordaid and UNOY are member of the working group drafting guidelines for localization for member states of the UN resolution. / / (Health): UHC strategy / (Civic space): / in context of IDPS constituency meetings

(Space for civil society): CSPPS has been involved in following formalised participation mechanisms: IDPS, g7+, CSW, Rome EGM / (Engendered peace- YPS): Successful organisation of the first global conversation on youth participation in peace processes in March, Helsinki.

Afghanistan Platform meeting with MFA on Geneva Conference Cordaid/Pax/CIVIC meeting on 2.community engagement of UN peace missions / BMO meeting with Directorate Human Rights and Multilateral Institutions / Ongoing participation in International Dialogue and next to this continious engagement in global SDG16+ community / Preparations for follow-up conference in Doha / preparations anniversary 2250
EPRM / IDPS / EAC meeting and CSO side-event in Juba. / Big Think on Justice in The Hague.

title.narrative: Number of initiatives resulting from organized multi-stakeholder dialogue

comment.narrative: (Engendered Peace - YPS): Dutch Youth Council (NJR) and the youth ambassadors, UNOY Peace builders have drafted a strategy to advocate with the Dutch MoFA and Ministry of Internal affairs on a international and domestic agendy on YPS. / IDLO, Cordaid, ICJ, ODI working with Pathfinders on CIJ advocacy, WG framework / (Health): UHC strategy / (Civic space): CSPPS COVID-19 statement as issued
(Space for civil society): Rome Civil Society Declaration on SDG16+

6 country strategies and 3 thematic strategies in preparation of the Brussels visit with SP partners. / VNR planning ahead of HLPF2019 / ACBAR position paper for Geneva Conference on Afghanistan. / Coordination meeting with Oxfam to discuss joint AU advocacy. / Active participation at KPSRL conference / Joint strategizing on future of SSR in DRC in Brussels with Search for Common Ground/EurAC. /

Establishment of WG on Customary and Informal Justice and SDG16+ / Through UNOY: Global Youth Advocacy Team (YAT), European Youth Advocacy Team (E-YAT), and African Youth Advocacy Team (A-YAT). Hard to quantify!

title.narrative: M) National and local decision makers adopt inclusive and legitimate policies and laws

comment.narrative: (Q4) (Economic opportunities): After being updated on current situation in Ogoni land 8 civil servants from different departments of the Dutch MoFA indicated that they would consider the recommendations for speeding up the clean-up led by HYPREP of two of Cordaid's Nigerian partner organizations in their future plans and policies for Nigeria. / (Q2) (Inclusive and engendered peace): New Dutch parliamentarians have received information about need for political and financial support to 1325 agenda. Contribution: as member of WO=MEN we have participated in discussions about messaging and also in a breakfast meeting with parliamentarians. / (Q2) (Space for Civil Society): Cordaid has joined the Concord Hub2 and 3 steering committees (on Financing for Development and on Space for CSOs - from politics to implementation; as such, has contributed to external conferences (eg European dev days) and bilateral meetings with EC staff responsible for implementation of the FFD3 agenda, in congruence and supporting SDG implementation. In the FFD3 agenda we push for the entitlement of citizens of the Global South to define their and their country’s sustainable development plans, for Tax Justice, for a genuine and innovative ODA, for Gender Equality, for EU policies and practice on private sector’s contributions to development finance, and for transparent and accountable Financing mechanisms for FCAS. / As CPDE European representative, and Concord Aid and development Effectiveness group member (Hub2), Cordaid staff is direct part of bilateral lobby talks with DEVCO A2 (aid & dev effectiveness unit). Recent talks in May and June 2017 have resulted in setting up a structured dialogue with the respective EC unit on the subject, supporting each other towards the GPEDC (global partnership for effective development cooperation). FCAS is a continuous point for attention for stakeholders, as recognised in the newly adopted EU Consensus for Development (June 2017) as well as in the EU Global Strategy (adopted in 2016), without due attention to FCAS, and the inclusive nature of national dynamics, the SDGs in those countries will not be achieved. This includes attention for financial and other means for implementation. Within the GPEDC dynamic: Cordaid staff is member of the GPEDC workstream nr1: Country level Implementation of development effectiveness principles (group lead by UNDP and OECD DAC) providing strategic support to countries to strengthen mechanisms for the implementation of effectiveness principles. / Lobby in the HL segment of the Global Conference on the Roadmap for SDG operationalization in FCAS - stressing the key role of CS in process of actualization of the agenda. / (Inclusive and engendered peace): New Dutch parliamentarians have received information about need for political and financial support to 1325 agenda. SP contribution: as member of WO=MEN we have participated in discussions about messaging and also in a breakfast meeting with parliamentarians. / (Q1) (Space for Civil Society): Contribution to CSO informal group (incl Concord, Eurodad, Oxfam) to discussions with the OECD / DAC. The OECD secretariat in Paris is on the side of CSOs in not supporting the aim of eu member states to use ODA for refugee costs in eu countries, but on the PSI instruments CSOs are side-lined (due to strong political engagement of the donor governments to support the role of private sector in development, using scarce ODA). This is particularly dangerous in FCAS. / (Economic opportunities): Further discussions with ON has resulted in strategy document with various steps to solidify PS engagement in FCAS. / Dutch MoFA continued fund-raising to enable citizens led policy processes on mining, oil and gas for local sustainable development and reducing risks. They are now at about 4,5 million Euro.

They are now at about 4,5 million Euro.

OUTCOME(S): Civic space: The CSPPS Annual Meeting provide an opportunity to operationalise key aspects of the IDPS Peace Vision into actionables as part of the CSPPS workplan.
Engendered peace - WPS: The Grand Bargain Friends of Gender Group and UN Women convened a consultation to discuss how to influence the outcome of the Africa regional conference by the Work Stream on localisation, to ensure a gender-responsive localisation and participation revolution. SP partner WIPC amplified the voices of local women’s groups, organisations and women affected by conflict in the global processes leading up to the Grand Bargain and in the national processes that followed. These fed into the discussions and outcomes of the thematic working group sessions of the Africa Regional Conference on Localisation of Humanitarian Aid held from 15th to 16th July 2019. The outcome document reflecting the conference’s priority issues included the gender-specific recommendations. The joint press release by the African Union Commission, the Swiss Government and IFRC highlighted the need for more support for women-led organisations.

Engendered peace - WPS: The Grand Bargain Friends of Gender Group and UN Women convened a consultation to discuss how to influence the outcome of the Africa regional conference by the Work Stream on localisation, to ensure a gender-responsive localisation and participation revolution. OUTCOME(S): (Space for civil society): Strategic contacts of UNDP provided a thorough and critical review of the draft Global Alliance-report for Reporting on SDG16. The Global Alliance said they would take inputs, suggested changes and recommendations on board after review. Members of the International Network on Conflict and Fragility (INCAF) and of the g7+ group of fragile and conflict-affected states represented in IDPS have reaeched an agreement on the IDPS Peace Vision.
(Engendered Peace (YPS and WPS)): Colombia has committed to develop a National Action Plan on UN resolution 2250 during the first global conversation on youth participation in peace processes in Helsinki (which was co-organized by SP partner UNOY Peace builders).

title.narrative: B) CSOs and Cordaid collect local evidence from target groups (with participatory data collection methodologies) for effective lobby and advocacy strategies and knowledge building

comment.narrative: (Q4) (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): A tailor made method (Barometer) has been introduced for the collection of stories and additional data on the daily safety in the community (with specific attention for women's safety). DRC and Afghanistan are actively implementing the Barometer process. Both countries are actively involved in the further development of the tool and these countries will provide examples for 'best practices' to inspire other countries. / (Inclusive Health services): Cordaid presented the main findings of the case study on UHC in DRC during a debate at the High Level Political Forum in New York in July 2017. The Executive Director of WHO, dr Tedros, and different ministers took part. The report underlines the important hurdles to reach UHC in DRC. / (Q1) (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): Our partner GNWP organized a side-event during CSW61 in New York policy briefing on Afghanistan where MWPS partners shared the experiences of local Afghan women. Presentation by Cordaid of experiences from the "barometer of local women's security" on knowledge sharing event hosted by the MoFA. Also presentation was given on barometer findings in Afghanistan in CSW61 in New York.

The Executive Director of WHO, dr Tedros, and different ministers took part. The report underlines the important hurdles to reach UHC in DRC. / (Q1) (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): Our partner GNWP organized a side-event during CSW61 in New York policy briefing on Afghanistan where MWPS partners shared the experiences of local Afghan women. OUTCOME(S): (Security and Access to Justice): In partnership with SIPRI and as a follow-up of previous joint research reports on legitimate stability in CAR and DRC, Cordaid will publish research reports beginning of December 2020, titled “Lessons learned of European Union Training Missions (EUTMs): Assessing the contribution of the EUTMs in CAR and Somalia to durable peace”.
(Civic Space): Cordaid and Hivos decided to update their joint report on civic space (‘Making civic space resilient’) and again consulted their partners to make an inventory of the different ways the COVID-19 pandemic (and the measures to fight it) have affected CSOs and their space to campaign for a more fair distribution of power, income and influence. Preliminary results of this research were well received by MFA and Minister Kaag. Meetings with Dutch MPs, Dutch MFA and officials in Brussels are organized to discuss policy recommendations.

OUTCOME(S): (Security and Access to Justice): In partnership with SIPRI and as a follow-up of previous joint research reports on legitimate stability in CAR and DRC, Cordaid will publish research reports beginning of December 2020, titled “Lessons learned of European Union Training Missions (EUTMs): Assessing the contribution of the EUTMs in CAR and Somalia to durable peace”.
(Civic Space): Cordaid and Hivos decided to update their joint report on civic space (‘Making civic space resilient’) and again consulted their partners to make an inventory of the different ways the COVID-19 pandemic (and the measures to fight it) have affected CSOs and their space to campaign for a more fair distribution of power, income and influence. Preliminary results of this research were well received by MFA and Minister Kaag. Meetings with Dutch MPs, Dutch MFA and officials in Brussels are organized to discuss policy recommendations.

OUTCOME(S): Engendered peace - WPS: Security council members participated in two open debates on WPS, during which the results of the WPS Barometer concerning sexual violence and conflict in South Sudan were presented and shared in April and October. Subsequently, Security council members used gender & sexual violence argument in the debate to continue the sanctions for South Sudan. / SP partner WIPC hosted a side event on the margins of CSW 63 (on 15th March 2019) where they presented findings of the study by WIPC with Universities of Tilburg, Makerere and Mbarara on the cost-benefit of social protection schemes such as cash transfer programmes and post trauma services for the empowerment of women in post-conflict Northern Uganda. It instigated dialogue on what must be done to ensure national government institutions and funding partners drive social protection programmes that advance feminist peace, the need for efforts addressing shrinking civic space and its impact on the women’s movement.
Security and access to Justice: The SP programme co-financed a data collection/research focused on local perceptions on international non-governmental organizations and United Nations peace operations in the provision of security and justice. In 2 countries (DRC and CAR), around 500 street interviews were conducted by local partners, supported by (local) research organisations. (https://www.sipri.org/publications/2019/sipri-policy-briefs/security-and-justice-car-and-drc-international-aims-local-expectations)Cordaid-ODI report on customary and informal justice harvested insights from three countries (Afghanistan, DRC and South Sudan) and translated those directly into policy-relevant recommendations to SDG16.3 stakeholders.The policy paper “diverse pathways to justice for all: supporting everyday justice providers to achieve SDG 16.3” debates towards recognition of the diverse ways in which people in a variety of contexts pursue redress and resolution of disputes, and why engagement with everyday justice providers is critical to achieving SDG 16.3. (https://www.cordaid.org/en/wp-content/uploads/sites/11/2019/09/Cordaid-Security-and-Justice-rapport-Sept2019.pdf)
Inclusive Health services: Cordaid commissioned a study to the School of Public Health of the University of Kinshasa to ask communities the pros and cons of Community Health Insurances or Mutuelles de Sante. The study was a contribution to the design of the national strategy on UHC in DRC.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered Peace (YPS and WPS)): A baseline study of the EU’s capability gaps to support youth participation in peacebuilding has been carried out. The report is an important milestone to support the evidence-based advocacy on Youth, Peace and Security towards the EU. A Policy paper and symposium report with compendium of best practices and lessons learnt of youth inclusion in negotiation and implementation of peace agreements has been the result after the first global conversation on youth participation in peace processes in Helsinki took place.

title.narrative: I) CSOs are influential in international multi-stakeholder alliances and platforms

comment.narrative:
(Civic space): IDPS stakeholders are informed about civil society considerations regarding the impact of C19 and take these on board in joint statement issued
(Engendered peace - YPS): Un Security council members have invited youth leaders from our network amongst others youth leader Gatwal Augustine Gatkuoth Yul (founder of Young-adult Empowerment Initiative from South Sudan) and Olla Al-Sakkaf (program coordinator at Youth Without Borders Organization for Development from Yemen) to speak about t the impact of COVID19 crisis in their countries and the need for an integrated peacebuilding approach, that addresses the multiple forms of exclusion of young people

(Civic space): IDPS stakeholders are informed about civil society considerations regarding the impact of C19 and take these on board in joint statement issued
(Engendered peace - YPS): Un Security council members have invited youth leaders from our network amongst others youth leader Gatwal Augustine Gatkuoth Yul (founder of Young-adult Empowerment Initiative from South Sudan) and Olla Al-Sakkaf (program coordinator at Youth Without Borders Organization for Development from Yemen) to speak about t the impact of COVID19 crisis in their countries and the need for an integrated peacebuilding approach, that addresses the multiple forms of exclusion of young people

(Q4) (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): New contacts were established with the Municipality of the Hague to influence the messaging and legacy of One Young World organized in October 2018 in the Hague. / UNDP sees the handbook on WPS as a good practice and wants to implement it in New Deal countries (first case for Somalia) in partnership with Cordaid. Department of State showed interest in the training that will be developed for the handbook and recognises the Barometer on WPS as an innovate and participatory way to collect data on countries that they have limited access to. / The representatives of the United Network of Young Peacebuilders representing 80 youth organizations, Cordaid and CSPPS have influenced the contents of the progress study on youth peace and security with recommendations for meaningful youth engagement. The study will be presented to the United Nations Security Council in April 2018. / (Space for Civil Society): Luncheon meeting at MOFA of WRR report 'Security in a World of Connections' - organized by the 5 DSH SPs (CARE NL, Cordaid, GPPAC, NIMD and Pax for Peace) led to intensified cooperation between these partnerships and DSH. This culminated in two consultation sessions on the updated International Security Strategy of the Government, for which a joint paper was prepared. / Inputs of CSPPS network to IDPS in process leading towards new and agreed upon IDPS strategy increased focus for lobby and advocacy around participation of women and youth - both in implementation of Stockholm commitments as well as efforts to secure and safeguard political space for CS / Cordaid DRC experience serves as resource within the framework of the World Bank GPSA pilot on do's and don’ts on enhancing social accountability in public service delivery in fragile states. / Afghan civil society organizations - in a meeting at the Dutch Embassy in Kabul, co-organized by Cordaid and ACBAR - have jointly reflected on the first National Voluntary SDG Review of the Afghan Government. The resulting report with recommendations was published online, shared with relevant stakeholders and was also shared during the HLPF with the Afghan Minister of Economy. As a result of this process, Cordaid's country director was asked to play a role in the follow-up process of SDG implementation as member of an advisory committee. / (Inclusive Health services): Cordaid keeps the importance of investments in UHC in fragile states on the international agenda. It did in New York at UN HLPF on DRC and at the UHC Forum in December in Tokyo on Afghanistan. The UHC2030 Civil Society Engagement Mechanism has become an important ally for WHO and WorldBank for all activities on UHC2030. Cordaid was one of the key players in this Civil Society Engagement Mechanism. / (Economic opportunities): In its funding decisions following the first call for proposals, EPRM gave due attention to the potential benefits for the population in mining areas as an important selection criterium. The just gold project in Ituri and its EPRM Local Advisory Committee took into account relevant Cordaid experiences in similar projects in the design of their credit component. / (Q2) (Space for Civil Society): Discussion took place in various fora to amplify voice of CS and to solidify greater support for CS role in IDPS and related processes [Stockholm, Dili etc] / (Inclusive and engendered peace): Follow-up plans have been discussed with UNOY and have also led to the formulation of a side event proposal for HLPF in July on YPS / During the Spring Meetings of the WB - April 21-23 2017, Cordaid presented in the session "Engaging Civil Society to Make a Difference in Situations of Fragility, Conflict and Violence" its CODESA program in DRC, supported by GPSA, that enhances social accountability mechanisms whereby local communities gain a stronger voice in access to and quality of health services they provide. see WB report of the session: http: / pubdocs.worldbank.org / en / 815711496934381316 / 2017-04.pdf. The content of the Cordaid presentation contributes to cementing the focus of the WB institution on engagement with CSOs. / (Economic opportunities): the board and secretariat of EPRM have discussed and decided the procedures / modalities of NGO member participation in LAC of PAC project Ituri. The outcome of these discussions was in line with our proposals. SP contribution: within NGO pillar we discussed possibility of joint LAC membership IPIS - Cordaid and convinced board of added-value. / Board has approved ToC of EPRM, in which more attention for interests of local communities than in original ToC. Together with other NGO's Solidaridad, PWYP we advocated for this in the ToC subgroup. / (Inclusive Health services): Increased cooperation between relevant Dutch CSOs on UHC, although there is no coalition in an institutionalized sense. / Online consultations organised for the EU decision makers in Brussels on UHC in Afghanistan. In June Cordaid prepared a session on UHC in DRC at the High Level Political Meeting in New York. The session itself will be in July. / Cordaid is very active to build in an inclusive Civil Society Mechanism for UHC. On average there are meetings every 2 weeks on this. / (Q1) (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): The IAWG on YPS continued its activities - current status of the Progress Study on YPS has been discussed. In the Netherlands Cordaid, UNOY and NJR partnered in successful event organized around UNSCR2250. CSPPS did support launch event in Sierra Leone and initiated discussion on this in context of Chad. The Platform has drafted a proposal to support study in Lake Chad region that is to feed into the YPS Progress Study. / (Space for Civil Society): Cordaid staff led EU CSO Delegation in meeting with EC Deputy DG DEVCO and his staff on the European next steps in the development effectiveness agenda, on the review of the EC Multi Annual Financial Framework, and on the preparation towards HLPF 2017 (with ao a focus on financing FCAS). Our new CEO, took over the board seat of GAI our former CEO. During CSW61 a side-event was organized (in the UN WOMEN building) aimed at (potential) donors. / Inclusive and (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): Contributed to expert meeting and public event to build on towards a Dutch coalition on UNSCR 2250: youth organisations gave input to the relevance of UNSCR 2250 to the Dutch context. Public event with representatives of youth political parties in the up-march of the elections on 15th of March 2017. First preparatory meeting in Burundi to build a meaningful coalition between World Vision, Search For Common Ground, Cordaid, UNWOMEN, local youth organizations and concept note on the way. Launch of UNSCR 2250 in Sierra Leone organized by the Youth Partnership for Peace and Development in close partnership with CSPPS, Cordaid and with a extensive representation of government, UN officials and civil society. Our new CEO, took over the board seat of GAI our former CEO. During CSW61 a side-event was organized (in the UN WOMEN building) aimed at (potential) donors. / (Inclusive Health services): Cordaid met with relevant Dutch health NGOs and institutes like KIT, Amref and WEMOS to cooperate more on UHC.

(Q4) (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): New contacts were established with the Municipality of the Hague to influence the messaging and legacy of One Young World organized in October 2018 in the Hague. / UNDP sees the handbook on WPS as a good practice and wants to implement it in New Deal countries (first case for Somalia) in partnership with Cordaid. Department of State showed interest in the training that will be developed for the handbook and recognises the Barometer on WPS as an innovate and participatory way to collect data on countries that they have limited access to. / The representatives of the United Network of Young Peacebuilders representing 80 youth organizations, Cordaid and CSPPS have influenced the contents of the progress study on youth peace and security with recommendations for meaningful youth engagement. The study will be presented to the United Nations Security Council in April 2018. / (Space for Civil Society): Luncheon meeting at MOFA of WRR report 'Security in a World of Connections' - organized by the 5 DSH SPs (CARE NL, Cordaid, GPPAC, NIMD and Pax for Peace) led to intensified cooperation between these partnerships and DSH. The resulting report with recommendations was published online, shared with relevant stakeholders and was also shared during the HLPF with the Afghan Minister of Economy. As a result of this process, Cordaid's country director was asked to play a role in the follow-up process of SDG implementation as member of an advisory committee. / (Inclusive Health services): Cordaid keeps the importance of investments in UHC in fragile states on the international agenda. SP contribution: within NGO pillar we discussed possibility of joint LAC membership IPIS - Cordaid and convinced board of added-value. / Board has approved ToC of EPRM, in which more attention for interests of local communities than in original ToC. Together with other NGO's Solidaridad, PWYP we advocated for this in the ToC subgroup. / (Inclusive Health services): Increased cooperation between relevant Dutch CSOs on UHC, although there is no coalition in an institutionalized sense. / Online consultations organised for the EU decision makers in Brussels on UHC in Afghanistan. In June Cordaid prepared a session on UHC in DRC at the High Level Political Meeting in New York. The session itself will be in July. / Cordaid is very active to build in an inclusive Civil Society Mechanism for UHC. On average there are meetings every 2 weeks on this. / (Q1) (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): The IAWG on YPS continued its activities - current status of the Progress Study on YPS has been discussed. In the Netherlands Cordaid, UNOY and NJR partnered in successful event organized around UNSCR2250. CSPPS did support launch event in Sierra Leone and initiated discussion on this in context of Chad. The Platform has drafted a proposal to support study in Lake Chad region that is to feed into the YPS Progress Study. / (Space for Civil Society): Cordaid staff led EU CSO Delegation in meeting with EC Deputy DG DEVCO and his staff on the European next steps in the development effectiveness agenda, on the review of the EC Multi Annual Financial Framework, and on the preparation towards HLPF 2017 (with ao a focus on financing FCAS). Our new CEO, took over the board seat of GAI our former CEO. During CSW61 a side-event was organized (in the UN WOMEN building) aimed at (potential) donors. / Inclusive and (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): Contributed to expert meeting and public event to build on towards a Dutch coalition on UNSCR 2250: youth organisations gave input to the relevance of UNSCR 2250 to the Dutch context. Public event with representatives of youth political parties in the up-march of the elections on 15th of March 2017. First preparatory meeting in Burundi to build a meaningful coalition between World Vision, Search For Common Ground, Cordaid, UNWOMEN, local youth organizations and concept note on the way. Launch of UNSCR 2250 in Sierra Leone organized by the Youth Partnership for Peace and Development in close partnership with CSPPS, Cordaid and with a extensive representation of government, UN officials and civil society. Our new CEO, took over the board seat of GAI our former CEO. During CSW61 a side-event was organized (in the UN WOMEN building) aimed at (potential) donors. / (Inclusive Health services): Cordaid met with relevant Dutch health NGOs and institutes like KIT, Amref and WEMOS to cooperate more on UHC.

(Q4) (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): New contacts were established with the Municipality of the Hague to influence the messaging and legacy of One Young World organized in October 2018 in the Hague. / UNDP sees the handbook on WPS as a good practice and wants to implement it in New Deal countries (first case for Somalia) in partnership with Cordaid. Department of State showed interest in the training that will be developed for the handbook and recognises the Barometer on WPS as an innovate and participatory way to collect data on countries that they have limited access to. / The representatives of the United Network of Young Peacebuilders representing 80 youth organizations, Cordaid and CSPPS have influenced the contents of the progress study on youth peace and security with recommendations for meaningful youth engagement. The study will be presented to the United Nations Security Council in April 2018. / (Space for Civil Society): Luncheon meeting at MOFA of WRR report 'Security in a World of Connections' - organized by the 5 DSH SPs (CARE NL, Cordaid, GPPAC, NIMD and Pax for Peace) led to intensified cooperation between these partnerships and DSH. This culminated in two consultation sessions on the updated International Security Strategy of the Government, for which a joint paper was prepared. / Inputs of CSPPS network to IDPS in process leading towards new and agreed upon IDPS strategy increased focus for lobby and advocacy around participation of women and youth - both in implementation of Stockholm commitments as well as efforts to secure and safeguard political space for CS / Cordaid DRC experience serves as resource within the framework of the World Bank GPSA pilot on do's and don’ts on enhancing social accountability in public service delivery in fragile states. / Afghan civil society organizations - in a meeting at the Dutch Embassy in Kabul, co-organized by Cordaid and ACBAR - have jointly reflected on the first National Voluntary SDG Review of the Afghan Government. The resulting report with recommendations was published online, shared with relevant stakeholders and was also shared during the HLPF with the Afghan Minister of Economy. As a result of this process, Cordaid's country director was asked to play a role in the follow-up process of SDG implementation as member of an advisory committee. / (Inclusive Health services): Cordaid keeps the importance of investments in UHC in fragile states on the international agenda. It did in New York at UN HLPF on DRC and at the UHC Forum in December in Tokyo on Afghanistan. The UHC2030 Civil Society Engagement Mechanism has become an important ally for WHO and WorldBank for all activities on UHC2030. Cordaid was one of the key players in this Civil Society Engagement Mechanism. / (Economic opportunities): In its funding decisions following the first call for proposals, EPRM gave due attention to the potential benefits for the population in mining areas as an important selection criterium. The just gold project in Ituri and its EPRM Local Advisory Committee took into account relevant Cordaid experiences in similar projects in the design of their credit component. / (Q2) (Space for Civil Society): Discussion took place in various fora to amplify voice of CS and to solidify greater support for CS role in IDPS and related processes [Stockholm, Dili etc] / (Inclusive and engendered peace): Follow-up plans have been discussed with UNOY and have also led to the formulation of a side event proposal for HLPF in July on YPS / During the Spring Meetings of the WB - April 21-23 2017, Cordaid presented in the session "Engaging Civil Society to Make a Difference in Situations of Fragility, Conflict and Violence" its CODESA program in DRC, supported by GPSA, that enhances social accountability mechanisms whereby local communities gain a stronger voice in access to and quality of health services they provide. see WB report of the session: http: / pubdocs.worldbank.org / en / 815711496934381316 / 2017-04.pdf. The content of the Cordaid presentation contributes to cementing the focus of the WB institution on engagement with CSOs. / (Economic opportunities): the board and secretariat of EPRM have discussed and decided the procedures / modalities of NGO member participation in LAC of PAC project Ituri. The outcome of these discussions was in line with our proposals. In June Cordaid prepared a session on UHC in DRC at the High Level Political Meeting in New York. The session itself will be in July. / Cordaid is very active to build in an inclusive Civil Society Mechanism for UHC. (Space for civil society): CSPPS policy brief and talking points presented in IDPS Steering Group Meeting . / CSPPS strategically positions itself in context of SDG16+ context on issues related to HLPF2019, which has led a formalized partnership with TAP Network (http://tapnetwork2030.org) and P4R and deepened partnership other actors like WFUNA/16Plus Forum

OUTCOME(S): (Civic Space): Within the IDPS tripartite structure, we spurred the release of a joint statement , calling upon all relevant stakeholders worldwide to abide by the motto of the 2030 Agenda: leaving no one behind. Drawing from our earlier experience with the Ebola outbreak, CSPPS recognized the importance of a holistic, cross-sectoral and whole-of-government response in tackling COVID-19 not only in fragile and conflict-affected settings, but in countries worldwide that may become more prone to violence due to the ongoing pandemic.

OUTCOME(S): Civic space: We perceive a growing interest from policy makers and politicians in The Netherlands and other EU countries (and Brussels) in the situation in Afghanistan, which amongst others has resulted in the planning of a debate on Afghanistan in Dutch Parliament in February 2020.
Engendered peace - WPS: CEPO (Grace John Kenyi, South Sudan) and MFFPS (Catherine Mabobori, Burundi) were able to address the 33rd Pre-Summit Civil Society Consultative Meeting on Gender Mainstreaming in the African Union (GIMAC) held on 3rd and 4th February 2019, and highlight the important peace-building role of women in protection of civilian sites and IDP camps in South Sudan as well as the need to include displaced women in peace building processes. GIMAC 33 bore the theme “Towards Gender-Responsive Durable Solutions to Forced Displacement”. In preparation for SP partner WIPC and Cordaid partners in Burundi, South Sudan, DRC and Uganda were consulted to identify key issues that could be amplified or advocated for during GIMAC based on the work and evidence of these organisations or networks. Partners were invited to speak during the different thematic panels. These issues were discussed and reflected in the final GIMAC recommendations which called for support for displaced women’s to occupy leadership positions in decision-making in IDP and refugee camps. The outcome document also called for the participation of women in the inter-Burundian dialogue and the need for its revival. The AU Women, Gender and Development Directorate received these recommendations to feed into the processes leading up to the AU Heads of State summit.
Security and access to Justice: Two visits to NYC with partners and colleagues which involved 2 partners and 1 local staff of Cordaid from DRC and CAR to share information and recommendations regarding the extension of the mandate of MONUSCO and MINUSCA to permanent representations, NYC-based NGOs and specific UN country teams.
Inclusive Health services: Cordaid and local CSOs in DRC contributed to the design of the national strategy for Universal Health Coverage in DRC.
Extractives: The OECD has been engaging civil society to a much larger degree, following the criticisms that have been raised last year with regards to poor support to civil society participation. Now, from the start, there has seen much more engagement on the part of the organizing committee to involve civil society. Many actors, not only CORDAID and EURAC, have advocated that civil society should be more involved in the OECD forum. This has been done by giving civil society more space to comment on the program, more preparatory calls, and more sessions available at the forum, which is a significant change.

OUTCOME(S): (Space for civil society): CS partners (CSPPS-members) put forward consolidated inputs in process of revising the IDPS Peace Vision Document, which were taken on board in finalized IDPS Peace vision statement.

title.narrative: A) Civil society partners (CSOs) and Cordaid increase their capacity to influence and engage in dialogue with policy makers, politicians and companies

comment.narrative:
(Civic space): Strategic coordination between CSO's and networks in The Netherlands and in other countries that work on protecting civic space has been very much strengthened in the last year; Both Partos, BMO and the Gender-Platform WO=MEN have chosen civic space as overarching topic for their policy influencing strategies, and more and more coordinate their inputs in policy and political discussions.
MFA very much aware of the incoherence between on the one hand the policy goal to protect space for CSOs and on the other hand increasing measures that actually let civic space shrink. The Ministry is actively participating in meeings organized by CSO networks on this topic, and in the case of counter-terrorist measures and legislation they have now the position to mitigate as much as possible the negative impact on the operational, political and financial space for CSOs
/ Strategic positioning of CSPPS in context of the COVID-19 response has been instrumental in dialogue with policy makers and other stakeholders in context of the IDPS. CSPPS statement and articles as issued have been well and appreciated and informed next steps in International Dialogue
(Engendered peace - YPS): UNOY Peace builders and their members participated and influenced the process of adapting a new UNSC YPS resolution. The reason that CSOs were invited was the excellent facilitation of the youth. Young people were invited to engage on the drafting process of the UN resolution. Therefore a youth consultaton with youth led CSOs from amongst others DRC, CAR, Nigeria, Libya, Iraq, Colombia was organized in May 2020 upon the request of SC members Domenican Republic and France. A shadow resolution was presented with focus on protection mechanism of young peace builders at risk, impact of covid19 crisis on youth and monitoring mechanism for implementation and localization of UN resolution 2250 was presented. The resolution is currently being negiotated and continous engagement is required.

MFA very much aware of the incoherence between on the one hand the policy goal to protect space for CSOs and on the other hand increasing measures that actually let civic space shrink. The resolution is currently being negiotated and continous engagement is required.

(Q4) (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): Partners in Burundi and DRC use the handbook on WPS as a reference for training and advocacy purposes. / (Q2) (Space for Civil Society): during this reporting period a number of targeted interventions have been implemented that have resulted in opportunities for CS partners to engage and dialogue with duty bearers; two key examples include the EDD2017 organized session on CAR and second is participation of both SPLA coordinator and CSPPS FP in a Nigerian Government organized meeting on the possible Nigerian membership of the IDPS. / Discussion was held with OECD Consultant on possible use of Cordaid Handbook on integrating gender in peacebuilding and state-building. / (Q1) (Space for Civil Society): At SP meeting at Cordaid concrete steps for solidifying cross-linkages between the SP program and CSPPS were discussed and agreed upon. / (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): Handbook was presented during a webinar (due to snowstorm side-event at CSW61 could not take place).

(Q4) (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): Partners in Burundi and DRC use the handbook on WPS as a reference for training and advocacy purposes. / (Q2) (Space for Civil Society): during this reporting period a number of targeted interventions have been implemented that have resulted in opportunities for CS partners to engage and dialogue with duty bearers; two key examples include the EDD2017 organized session on CAR and second is participation of both SPLA coordinator and CSPPS FP in a Nigerian Government organized meeting on the possible Nigerian membership of the IDPS. / Discussion was held with OECD Consultant on possible use of Cordaid Handbook on integrating gender in peacebuilding and state-building. / (Q1) (Space for Civil Society): At SP meeting at Cordaid concrete steps for solidifying cross-linkages between the SP program and CSPPS were discussed and agreed upon. / (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): Handbook was presented during a webinar (due to snowstorm side-event at CSW61 could not take place).

(Space for civil society): For the first time EU/DEVCO has signed a grant agreement with CSPPS, which is manifest recognition from EU-side on role CSPPS is playing in supporting CS engagement in FCAS. / (Extractives): Participants of the Goma workshop about initiatives for responsible mineral chains (in conflict and high risk areas and their impact on local communities) have prepared an agenda for action with recommendations for different stakeholder groups, including international stakeholders like EU and ICGLR. / CSO partners from the SP program from 6 countries have prepared and carried out joint lobby initiatives with several stakeholders in Brussels (DEVCO working group on South Sudan, several EC directorates working on conflict minerals, Dutch permanent representation in the EU Africa working group.)

(Space for civil society): For the first time EU/DEVCO has signed a grant agreement with CSPPS, which is manifest recognition from EU-side on role CSPPS is playing in supporting CS engagement in FCAS. / (Extractives): Participants of the Goma workshop about initiatives for responsible mineral chains (in conflict and high risk areas and their impact on local communities) have prepared an agenda for action with recommendations for different stakeholder groups, including international stakeholders like EU and ICGLR. / CSO partners from the SP program from 6 countries have prepared and carried out joint lobby initiatives with several stakeholders in Brussels (DEVCO working group on South Sudan, several EC directorates working on conflict minerals, Dutch permanent representation in the EU Africa working group.)

OUTCOME(S): Civic space: The Ready for Review project has provided ample opportunities to civil society to enhance their capacities to influence and directly engage in dialogue process around the VNR-process in their respective countries. The Ready for Review (R4R) is a CSPPS project to support civil society engagement in fragile and conflict- affected (FCAS) countries participating in the 2019 Voluntary National Reviews (VNR). CSPPS sought to ensure and foster meaningful inclusion, participation and contribution of national and local civil society organizations in government-led SDG16 consultation, review and validation processes. The Reporting for the Future report describes the efforts of CSPPS members and partners to strengthen CSO engagement and capacity in selected countries for the VNR process in 2019. / The Rome Civil Society Declaration on SDG16+ (as manifested during the earlier reporting period) did prove to have an impact on the declaration coming out of the SDG summit.
Engendered peace - WPS: Local colleagues from Afghanistan and partner organisation AWN increased their presence and visibility at the international stage after mentoring and coaching from experts at Global Office. This resulted in both our Cordaid colleague and our partner speaking at high level panels in the UN working with policy makers with coverage and good (international) feedback). (https://www.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2019/3/news-women-peace-and-security-experts-look-ahead-to-2020) / Coaching and support of colleague from partner from South Sudan (Eve) in first lobby mission with WPS Barometer report in NY. Presenting the preliminary findings of the report. Preparing the trip, discussing meeting techniques. Resulted in a stronger and better informed proposal for CSW in 2019. / As a result of the training “Integrating gender in peace & state building” in August 2019 the country offices and local partners included more international lobby and advocacy opportunities in the planning for 2020. Being more aware of the opportunities to do shared lobby at various levels.
Engendered peace - YPS: Five youth leaders from Cameroon, Nigeria, Burundi, Zimbabwe, Egypt, as well two UNOY representatives from the international secretariat - Global Youth advocacy team carried out a lobby mission to the African Union. This resulted in an arrangement with the AU Youth envoy Ms. Aya Chebbi to team up during her lobby mission in 2020 throughout Africa with the UNOY members, providing opportunities for the members to address their local realities and the relevance of inclusion of youth during the mission with policy decision makers. Furthermore, GIZ expressed interest to work with UNOY Peace builders & the Post Conflict Reconstruction & Development department of the AU to develop and provide curriculum for youth sensitive training to strengthen peace keeping missions.
Security and access to Justice: Preparation of missions with local partners from DRC and CAR to the UN in New York. During these missions, the meetings with policy makers were prepared, specific messages were developed per actor and every meeting was evaluated. / Local partners from all the six SP countries as well as local Cordaid colleagues have identified potential entry-points to introduce result-based management and financing system with national institutions and stakeholders as well as to identify potential willing allies within state institutions for more result-based working. The partners working on security and justice participated in an exchange workshop on approaches and best practices to improve accountability and quality of funding of security, justice and local governance actors. Based on this first exposure, follow-up workshops were held in Afghanistan, DRC and CAR.
Inclusive Health services: Cordaid and local CSOs in Afghanistan and DRC contributed to the Devex articles and multimedia feature on Unversal Health Coverage in DRC, South-Sudan and Afghanistan. Colleagues of Cordaid and CSOs had to learn to present their work on UHC to a wider audience.

OUTCOME(S): Civic space: The Ready for Review project has provided ample opportunities to civil society to enhance their capacities to influence and directly engage in dialogue process around the VNR-process in their respective countries. The Ready for Review (R4R) is a CSPPS project to support civil society engagement in fragile and conflict- affected (FCAS) countries participating in the 2019 Voluntary National Reviews (VNR). CSPPS sought to ensure and foster meaningful inclusion, participation and contribution of national and local civil society organizations in government-led SDG16 consultation, review and validation processes. The Reporting for the Future report describes the efforts of CSPPS members and partners to strengthen CSO engagement and capacity in selected countries for the VNR process in 2019. / The Rome Civil Society Declaration on SDG16+ (as manifested during the earlier reporting period) did prove to have an impact on the declaration coming out of the SDG summit.
Engendered peace - WPS: Local colleagues from Afghanistan and partner organisation AWN increased their presence and visibility at the international stage after mentoring and coaching from experts at Global Office. This resulted in both our Cordaid colleague and our partner speaking at high level panels in the UN working with policy makers with coverage and good (international) feedback). (https://www.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2019/3/news-women-peace-and-security-experts-look-ahead-to-2020) / Coaching and support of colleague from partner from South Sudan (Eve) in first lobby mission with WPS Barometer report in NY. Presenting the preliminary findings of the report. Preparing the trip, discussing meeting techniques. Resulted in a stronger and better informed proposal for CSW in 2019. / As a result of the training “Integrating gender in peace & state building” in August 2019 the country offices and local partners included more international lobby and advocacy opportunities in the planning for 2020. Being more aware of the opportunities to do shared lobby at various levels.
Engendered peace - YPS: Five youth leaders from Cameroon, Nigeria, Burundi, Zimbabwe, Egypt, as well two UNOY representatives from the international secretariat - Global Youth advocacy team carried out a lobby mission to the African Union. This resulted in an arrangement with the AU Youth envoy Ms. Aya Chebbi to team up during her lobby mission in 2020 throughout Africa with the UNOY members, providing opportunities for the members to address their local realities and the relevance of inclusion of youth during the mission with policy decision makers. Furthermore, GIZ expressed interest to work with UNOY Peace builders & the Post Conflict Reconstruction & Development department of the AU to develop and provide curriculum for youth sensitive training to strengthen peace keeping missions.
Security and access to Justice: Preparation of missions with local partners from DRC and CAR to the UN in New York. During these missions, the meetings with policy makers were prepared, specific messages were developed per actor and every meeting was evaluated. / Local partners from all the six SP countries as well as local Cordaid colleagues have identified potential entry-points to introduce result-based management and financing system with national institutions and stakeholders as well as to identify potential willing allies within state institutions for more result-based working. The partners working on security and justice participated in an exchange workshop on approaches and best practices to improve accountability and quality of funding of security, justice and local governance actors. Based on this first exposure, follow-up workshops were held in Afghanistan, DRC and CAR.
Inclusive Health services: Cordaid and local CSOs in Afghanistan and DRC contributed to the Devex articles and multimedia feature on Unversal Health Coverage in DRC, South-Sudan and Afghanistan. Colleagues of Cordaid and CSOs had to learn to present their work on UHC to a wider audience.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): Two UNOY members briefed the UN Security Council at the Open VTC Debate on YPS: Olla Al-Sakkaf from Yemen and Gatwal Gatkouth from South Sudan/Uganda.
(Inclusive Health): DEVEX produced a visual story on Cordaid’s work for UHC in DRC and widely disseminated the visual story receiving 4 million views.
(Civic Space): Dutch newspaper De Volkskrant wrote different articles and an op-ed on the results of development aid in Uruzgan and Afghanistan. They underlined Cordaid’s advocacy message that only a long-term community-based approach bears fruit in fragile context. Cordaid contracted TLO to do an assessment of the results of development-aid in Uruzgan 10 years after the departure of the Dutch troops

OUTCOME(S): (Security and Access to Justice): Partners in CAR and DRC have increased capacities in security sector reform, justice reform and conducting security and justice sector assesments through training faciliated by ASSN. In CAR the SSR unit from MINUSCA assisted in the training and in DRC the REC for Central Africa (ECCAS). The strategic collaboration with MINUSCA has helped to identify as a strategic partner with a partially common agenda. (Engendered Peace (YPS and WPS)): Policy decision makers and other relevant stakeholders in Afghanistan have been introduced via a policy brief and dissemination event on the barriers and motivators and impact of youth led civic engagement for peace building in Afghanistan. The policy brief and dissemination event was organized by UNOY member Afghan Progressive Thinking (APT) in partnership with UNOY http://unoy.org/wp-content/uploads/Policy-Brief-Afghanistan-Beyond-Dividing-Lines.pdf. (Inclusive Health): DEVEX is raising awareness for the High Level Meeting on UHC in New York in September through videos and articles also on the work of Cordaid in DRC and Afghanistan.

title.narrative: N) National government institutions, international development actors and multinational companies implement laws and policies favourable to the target communities with transparent practices & systems

comment.narrative: (Q4) (Space for Civil Society): A very positive, constructive response from minister Kaag on a quick scan - a joint project with Hivos and Open State Foundation - about the transparency (budgets, spending and contracts) of the top 20 of Dutch-funded multilateral organization was presented to Dutch parliamentarians and Dutch ministers of Finance, Foreign Affairs, Foreign Trade and Development Cooperation and Defense. / (Economic opportunities): New Dutch Members of Parliament working on corporate responsibility of Dutch companies sourcing from or operating in fragile contexts received orientation on the need for binding regulation on human rights due diligence as an instrument for dealing with negative social, economic, environmental and human rights impacts in their supply chains, so as to prepare them for parliamentary debates on this issue. / (Q2) (Economic opportunities): EC Brussels is discussing with NGOs about accompanying measures to new EU conflict minerals regulation, especially in relation to funding available for those accompanying measures. SP contribution: as a member of EURAC working group natural resources we have shared insights based on our extractives trajectory in DRC. / (Q1) (Space for Civil Society): National Policy forum for Development SDG researches are directly plugged into NL talks with MOFA. Also the southern countries researches are plugged into the capacity building and awareness raising trajectories at SPLA country level (eg Afghanistan). / (Inclusive and Engendered Peace): In Afghanistan partners have been pushing government to implement 1325. / (Economic opportunities): IAIA, together with representatives of 2 local partner organizations MOSOP and CERDH, carried out a scoping mission in preparation of an integrated environmental, social, human rights and gender (ESHRG) baseline study in Ogoniland (Nigeria) planned for the second half of 2017.

(Space for civil society): Cordaid, Hivos and Open State Foundation / developed, after a thorough research on available data of 20 multilateral organizations (UN organizations, World Bank and NATO), the website https://openstate.eu/nl/openmultilaterals/ to make information on awarded contracts publicly accessible. This in order to raise awareness with policy makers and politicians on the importance of open data, and to put pressure on multilateral organizations to open up their data in a more consistent manner . / The Security Council adopted resolution 2419 (2018) with which the UNSC reaffirms its commitment to the comprehensive implementation of UNSCR 2250. UNOY Peace builders contributed to different milestones at policy level. / (Inclusive health services): The Minister of Health in DRC has asked to be part of the preparation of a follow-up workshop after a first training by KIT and PNMPS in Kinshasa, because he wants the workshop to produce policy document for health insurance. He also asked Cordaid for input for policy on health insurances Cooperation with National Police following lobby through the SG of MoH in Geneva.

OUTCOME(S): Civic space: The topic of (too limited) transparency of multilateral organizations is now a returning issue in debates, with a number of MPs taking a strong interest in it and asking regularly critical questions to the minister.
Extractives: The EC has been stressing verbally the fact that companies are responsible for their own due diligence even when they are part of industry schemes. Attention to this has been reiterated both by EC representatives and by MEPs during EP Committee meetings for the accreditation of industry schemes / company. There has been not a legislative change to address this in the Regulation as consultations of CORDAID and EURAC with MEPs lead to the conclusion that there was no political opportunity for that.

OUTCOME(S): Civic space: The topic of (too limited) transparency of multilateral organizations is now a returning issue in debates, with a number of MPs taking a strong interest in it and asking regularly critical questions to the minister.
Extractives: The EC has been stressing verbally the fact that companies are responsible for their own due diligence even when they are part of industry schemes. Attention to this has been reiterated both by EC representatives and by MEPs during EP Committee meetings for the accreditation of industry schemes / company. There has been not a legislative change to address this in the Regulation as consultations of CORDAID and EURAC with MEPs lead to the conclusion that there was no political opportunity for that.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): A new UN resolution on Youth, Peace and Security adapted in 2020, an action-oriented commitment after consultation and inputs from youth leaders of our global Youth leaders network. The Resolution 2535, co-sponsored by France and the Dominican Republic, reiterated and strengthened the commitment of member states in the global YPS agenda, already outlined in UNSCR 2250 (2015) and 2419 (2018). The member states Dominican Republic and France requested these consultations before tabling the resolution. Our partner UNOY Peace builders supported through the program has organised youth and CSO consultations to feed in new resolution on YPS (2535). The resolution 2535 as the most action-oriented commitment of the Security Council also introduced new language on full and meaningful participation of ‘young people in humanitarian action’ and ‘protection of civic space’.

OUTCOME(S): (Space for civil society): 4 MPs of the Dutch Parliament used and quoted an advocacy letter sent to parliament on the occasion of the debate on the Spring Meeting of the World Bank, as a result of which minister Kaag agreed to push for more transparency of (contract) data by the World Bank. In the letter Cordaid, Hivos and the Open State Foundation referred to the publication of 400.000 contracts of multilateral organizations on the website https://openstate.eu/nl/openmultilaterals. We were invited by MP Wybren van Haga (VVD) to present our findings in more detail.

title.narrative: H) Government institutions, private sector and civil society develop structural dialogue and engagement

comment.narrative: (Q4) (Space for Civil Society): Consultation process in Kabul between Afghan government and CSO's on SDG implementation and presentation of the first voluntary SDG review report has resulted in a review and implementation infrastructure, in which CSO's play a meaningful role. / Partnership with IEP on SDG16.3 and invitation for follow-up discussion with Pathfinders at MoFA and involvement in discussions on role of Minister Kaag of Dutch MoFA in Justice Task Force / A parliamentary debate on Afghanistan, lobby meeting with parliamentarians of CDA, VVD, SP, D66 and PvdA and a work visit in Cordaid's offices of CDA parliamentarian have led to good working relations with a critical mass in parliament when it comes to working in and on fragility. This has led for example to parliamentary questions on the situation in DRC at the initiative of the Christian Union. The Afghanistan Platform, chaired by Cordaid, has been reanimated and combined with the NAP 1325 working group on Afghanistan. Participation from both MoFA side and NGOs is steadily increasing. Meetings are used strategically as input opportunities for the Dutch lead role in the UNSC on Afghanistan. / (Economic opportunities): The four (new) spokespersons on WPS of different political parties in the Dutch Parliament appreciated the recommendations in relation to the Dutch women / youth, peace & security policy by the SP coordinators of 5 countries and showed interest in future contacts on these issues. The D66 spokesperson had a follow-up meeting on the situation in CAR. / (Inclusive Health services): The UHC Day events in Kabul, Bukavu, Yabello (Ethiopia), Juba and Tokyo increased public commitment of national and international policy makers to UHC. / (Q2) (Space for Civil Society): During the reporting period a IDPS SGM and IWG-level meeting were held in parallel to the WB Spring Meeting. Representatives from CSPPS membership were invited to participate and shared CS position on issues discussed / Cordaid has contributed during 2nd quarter to the Partos consolidated input towards the Dutch National Voluntary Review for the July HLPF in New York. The input is striking the balance between external and internal SDG implementation efforts of Dutch MOFA with a special focus on need for implementation of New Deal principles, incl the one on "inclusive politics". This discussion with MOFA contributes to clarifying the focus on SDGs implementation in FCAS. / (Economic opportunities): EC Brussels is discussing with NGOs about accompanying measures to new EU conflict minerals regulation, especially in relation to funding available for those accompanying measures. As a member of EURAC working group natural resources we have shared insights based on our extractives trajectory in DRC. / (Q1) (Space for Civil Society): CSPPS has been in dialogue with other IDPS constituencies on new IDPS strategy to further effectuate and operationalize the Stockholm Declaration. / (Security and Access to Justice): Talks are ongoing with potential networks and partners at the African Union level, to jointly advocate on security &justice provision. Capacity development and in-country advocacy of partners will be more closely linked to any potential effort in influencing AU. / (Economic opportunities): E-mail and skype discussions with PWYP about Theory of Change EPRM (Cordaid participated in the ToC working group). They will decide on their EPRM membership in the GA of April. EPRM board with EPRM secretariat (Cordaid is not a board member) finalizes MoU. The final vote on the new EU legislation on conflict minerals will be end of March. Legislation cannot be changed anymore, but we will try to influence the so-called accompanying measures. We have commented on draft of EurAc document on this topic. / (Inclusive Health services): Cordaid is participating in UHC2030 Alliance its Civil Society Engagement Mechanism. Cordaid has a prominent role in participating in 2 working groups to establish this mechanism.

(Q4) (Space for Civil Society): Consultation process in Kabul between Afghan government and CSO's on SDG implementation and presentation of the first voluntary SDG review report has resulted in a review and implementation infrastructure, in which CSO's play a meaningful role. / Partnership with IEP on SDG16.3 and invitation for follow-up discussion with Pathfinders at MoFA and involvement in discussions on role of Minister Kaag of Dutch MoFA in Justice Task Force / A parliamentary debate on Afghanistan, lobby meeting with parliamentarians of CDA, VVD, SP, D66 and PvdA and a work visit in Cordaid's offices of CDA parliamentarian have led to good working relations with a critical mass in parliament when it comes to working in and on fragility. This has led for example to parliamentary questions on the situation in DRC at the initiative of the Christian Union. The Afghanistan Platform, chaired by Cordaid, has been reanimated and combined with the NAP 1325 working group on Afghanistan. Participation from both MoFA side and NGOs is steadily increasing. Meetings are used strategically as input opportunities for the Dutch lead role in the UNSC on Afghanistan. / (Economic opportunities): The four (new) spokespersons on WPS of different political parties in the Dutch Parliament appreciated the recommendations in relation to the Dutch women / youth, peace & security policy by the SP coordinators of 5 countries and showed interest in future contacts on these issues. The D66 spokesperson had a follow-up meeting on the situation in CAR. / (Inclusive Health services): The UHC Day events in Kabul, Bukavu, Yabello (Ethiopia), Juba and Tokyo increased public commitment of national and international policy makers to UHC. / (Q2) (Space for Civil Society): During the reporting period a IDPS SGM and IWG-level meeting were held in parallel to the WB Spring Meeting. Representatives from CSPPS membership were invited to participate and shared CS position on issues discussed / Cordaid has contributed during 2nd quarter to the Partos consolidated input towards the Dutch National Voluntary Review for the July HLPF in New York. The input is striking the balance between external and internal SDG implementation efforts of Dutch MOFA with a special focus on need for implementation of New Deal principles, incl the one on "inclusive politics". This discussion with MOFA contributes to clarifying the focus on SDGs implementation in FCAS. / (Economic opportunities): EC Brussels is discussing with NGOs about accompanying measures to new EU conflict minerals regulation, especially in relation to funding available for those accompanying measures. As a member of EURAC working group natural resources we have shared insights based on our extractives trajectory in DRC. / (Q1) (Space for Civil Society): CSPPS has been in dialogue with other IDPS constituencies on new IDPS strategy to further effectuate and operationalize the Stockholm Declaration. / (Security and Access to Justice): Talks are ongoing with potential networks and partners at the African Union level, to jointly advocate on security &justice provision. Capacity development and in-country advocacy of partners will be more closely linked to any potential effort in influencing AU. / (Economic opportunities): E-mail and skype discussions with PWYP about Theory of Change EPRM (Cordaid participated in the ToC working group). We have commented on draft of EurAc document on this topic. / (Inclusive Health services): Cordaid is participating in UHC2030 Alliance its Civil Society Engagement Mechanism. Cordaid has a prominent role in participating in 2 working groups to establish this mechanism.

(Q4) (Space for Civil Society): Consultation process in Kabul between Afghan government and CSO's on SDG implementation and presentation of the first voluntary SDG review report has resulted in a review and implementation infrastructure, in which CSO's play a meaningful role. / Partnership with IEP on SDG16.3 and invitation for follow-up discussion with Pathfinders at MoFA and involvement in discussions on role of Minister Kaag of Dutch MoFA in Justice Task Force / A parliamentary debate on Afghanistan, lobby meeting with parliamentarians of CDA, VVD, SP, D66 and PvdA and a work visit in Cordaid's offices of CDA parliamentarian have led to good working relations with a critical mass in parliament when it comes to working in and on fragility. This has led for example to parliamentary questions on the situation in DRC at the initiative of the Christian Union. The Afghanistan Platform, chaired by Cordaid, has been reanimated and combined with the NAP 1325 working group on Afghanistan. Participation from both MoFA side and NGOs is steadily increasing. Meetings are used strategically as input opportunities for the Dutch lead role in the UNSC on Afghanistan. / (Economic opportunities): The four (new) spokespersons on WPS of different political parties in the Dutch Parliament appreciated the recommendations in relation to the Dutch women / youth, peace & security policy by the SP coordinators of 5 countries and showed interest in future contacts on these issues. The D66 spokesperson had a follow-up meeting on the situation in CAR. / (Inclusive Health services): The UHC Day events in Kabul, Bukavu, Yabello (Ethiopia), Juba and Tokyo increased public commitment of national and international policy makers to UHC. / (Q2) (Space for Civil Society): During the reporting period a IDPS SGM and IWG-level meeting were held in parallel to the WB Spring Meeting. Representatives from CSPPS membership were invited to participate and shared CS position on issues discussed / Cordaid has contributed during 2nd quarter to the Partos consolidated input towards the Dutch National Voluntary Review for the July HLPF in New York. The input is striking the balance between external and internal SDG implementation efforts of Dutch MOFA with a special focus on need for implementation of New Deal principles, incl the one on "inclusive politics". This discussion with MOFA contributes to clarifying the focus on SDGs implementation in FCAS. / (Economic opportunities): EC Brussels is discussing with NGOs about accompanying measures to new EU conflict minerals regulation, especially in relation to funding available for those accompanying measures. As a member of EURAC working group natural resources we have shared insights based on our extractives trajectory in DRC. / (Q1) (Space for Civil Society): CSPPS has been in dialogue with other IDPS constituencies on new IDPS strategy to further effectuate and operationalize the Stockholm Declaration. / (Security and Access to Justice): Talks are ongoing with potential networks and partners at the African Union level, to jointly advocate on security &justice provision. Capacity development and in-country advocacy of partners will be more closely linked to any potential effort in influencing AU. / (Economic opportunities): E-mail and skype discussions with PWYP about Theory of Change EPRM (Cordaid participated in the ToC working group). They will decide on their EPRM membership in the GA of April. EPRM board with EPRM secretariat (Cordaid is not a board member) finalizes MoU. The final vote on the new EU legislation on conflict minerals will be end of March. Legislation cannot be changed anymore, but we will try to influence the so-called accompanying measures. We have commented on draft of EurAc document on this topic. / (Inclusive Health services): Cordaid is participating in UHC2030 Alliance its Civil Society Engagement Mechanism. Cordaid has a prominent role in participating in 2 working groups to establish this mechanism.

OUTCOME(S): Civic space: The CSPPS Annual Meeting also featured the launch of the Ready to Engage report that provides an introduction for civil society organisations and other stakeholders on the role of business in fragile and conflict-affected settings. The document was well received by all IDPS constituencies./ In the Ready for Review (R4R) project former rebel-strongholds and with broader groups of beneficiaries were consulted as part of the civil society engagement of the 2019 Voluntary National Review (VNR) in CAR.
Engendered peace - WPS: The Office of the AUC Special Envoy on WPS regarding UNSCR 1325 advocacy at regional level has strengthened their partnership with programme partners WIPC. The Special Advisor/Chief of Staff in Addis Ababa and WIPC discussed advocacy opportunities and the Special Envoy’s plans to revitalise the Silencing the Guns project and create a campaign for women’s participation. This partnership between WIPC and the Office of the Special Envoy on WPS is a valuable first step in facilitating access for other women’s organisations and women/young women to access relevant regional platforms and to exercise their influence to advance the WPS agenda at both national and regional levels. / United States government agreed after extensive lobby by Cordaid and partners to structurally include women in the Afghan peace processes. (https://tolonews.com/afghanistan/us-congress-wants-afghan-women%E2%80%99s-presence-peace-talks)
Engendered peace - YPS: Youth leaders from Afghanistan, the Netherlands (Youth ambassador to the UN), Libya (NAP1325 program) and Iraq, came together with governments officials (MoFA, Kabul Embassy), Dutch and International NGO's and Academics in an expert meeting 10th of December in The Hague. They discussed the challenges and lessons learnt on youth inclusive peace processes during the 4th anniversary of UNSCR 2250 and the youth activists gave recommendations on the importance of youth inclusive peace processes and the current challenges in conflict-affected countries such as Afghanistan. Initial talks resulted in openness about more cooperation and involvement of Cordaid and UNOY to discuss more meaningful engagement of the MoFA on UNSCR 2250 in terms of (foreign) policies.
The launch of the report 'mapping the progress of youth, peace and security in the European Union' brought together 27 representatives of the (EU) bodies, CSOs and young peace builders in Brussels on the 18th of September. The EU is a key player on youth, peace and security has made significant progress in a short period of time to engage with the YPS agenda with thanks also to different L&A efforts. The mapping has also been presented in the Youth portal of the EU.

OUTCOME(S): (Security and Access to Justice): EU officials had a frank discussion with civil society representatives about the current and future strategy of the EU in the Great Lakes. The EU policy makers shared confidential information on the political situation in DRC and Burundi. (Inclusive Health): NGOs requested assistance from Cordaid to convene a structural dialogue to promote sustainable healthcare in Afghanistan. Together with Cordaid national and international NGOs that work on healthcare to prepared the symposium on sustainable healthcare in Kabul. (Extractives): Policy makers of DG DEVCO in Brussels gained better insight in recent developments in DRC which will guide their decisions regarding artisanal miners and local communities. Participants of an OECD workshop in April about initiatives for responsible mineral chains in conflict and high risk areas and their impact on local communities have formulated recommendations and an agenda for action for different stakeholder groups. Policy makers participating in the COMECE workshop in Brussels showed keen interest in hearing about the impact of the conflict minerals regulation on the ground (DRC) and the recommendations of the Goma workshop; they were particularly concerned about the implementation of the EC Directive. (Bob)

OUTCOME(S): (Security and Access to Justice): Afghan government, donors engaging with civil society around the need to prioritize access to justice and rule of law in international assistance to Afghanistan, especially vis-à-vis the Afghan peace process. Distinctive voice of Afghan local partners and Cordaid on transitional justice established, through launch of a policy-relevant report with ICTJ on transitional justice in very fragile contexts, highlighting the role of justice and rule of law in the Afghan peace process prior to the Nov 2020 pledging conference, and other actions.
(Civic Space): Cordaid and the Knowledge Platform organized a series of exchanges on the link between religion and the women, peace and security agenda. These meetings were well attended, and one of the speakers was the special envoy for religion of the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Another speaker was Azza Karam.

title.narrative: D) CSOs organize in networks to build collaborate capacity for lobby and advocacy

comment.narrative:
(Civic space): Consortium of civil society actors working in and on Libya agree on follow-up trajectory following VNR / SDG16 workshop
(Engendered peace - YPS): UNOY, NJR (Dutch Youth Council) and Cordaid have joined forces together to develop a comprehensive strategy to influence the Dutch government on a domestic and foreign agenda on YPS
(Engendered peace - WPS): Taskforce was set up and Concept Note developed on the inclusive peace process in coordination with 'new' partners USIP, FBA & EIP to improve coordination and information sharing, to avoid doubling activities on the Afghan peace process. / Further development Alliance for women in peacebuilding together with GeorgeTown institute / Shared planning and strategizing with ENNA on upcoming donor conference for Nordic + countries on Afghanistan - Cordaid one of hosting organisations

(Q4) (Space for Civil Society): Cross-fertilization between CSPPS and SP partners in countries has catalysed strategic thinking on alignment and collaboration in 2018. / (Economic opportunities): In the new civic space initiative, a group of SP programs and DSO decided to also strategize and learn among SP's about how to deal with shrinking civic space. This joint reflection and learning does not only take place in the Netherlands, but also in a number of pilot countries, where SPs, their local partners and NL Embassy decided to start coordinating around civic space and test new approaches following an action learning method. / (Q2) (Space for Civil Society): meetings of CSPPS membership were held as planned on regular basis / (Inclusive Health services): Meetings with Cordaid colleagues in The Hague working on health program in DRC to align program and advocacy for Universal Health Coverage in DRC. / Building networks inside and outside Netherlands as instruments to push UHC and HSS. Lobby in Geneva at WHO by emphasising UHC reality in specific countries.
