(Space for civil society): CSPPS brief and talking points discussed and agreed upon in consultation with CSPPS members as input on new IDPS vision statement. / A group of Dutch NGOs jointly lobbied to be invited to the consultation on the South Sudan multiannual country strategy of MFA and provided input. As a result Policy makers at MFA and Embassy consider several Cordaid policy asks in the South Sudan multiannual country strategy, e.g. on need to protect civic space. / (Engendered Peace): In New York CSOs have started to organize to work on common agenda with CSOs working on 1325 worldwide to influence implementation agenda and report by UN in 2020. Strong commitment and ownership with CSOs needs to be result in a clear agenda and advocacy. Cordaid one of the main organisations to lead this process. / Burundian CSOs, including two UNOY partners, brought together more than 200 young people (74 girls and 137 boys) from the whole country, 18 provinces in total, in a two days Forum with national decision-makers on the relevance of youth participation in peacebuilding and security processes (localisation of UNSCR 2250 in Burundi). / (Extractives): NGO pillar of EPRM has decided to propose the formation of a consultation group of local NGOs in producing countries to advice EPRM about how to ensure that their activities contribute to the ultimate goal of improving lives of miners and communities.

OUTCOME(S): (Security and Access to Justice): A 2-year cycle of research and advocacy on customary and informal justice culminated in establishment of the Working Group on CIJ and SDG16+, bringing together an informal core group of justice stakeholders to build consensus on the role of CIJ systems in achieving justice for all.

OUTCOME(S): Civic space: Strong interest by MFA in evidence, academic and CSO research on conflict prevention, peacebuilding and access to justice. This was also emphasized by the Cordaid/SIPRI research on peace missions in DRC and CAR and the Cordaid/ODI report on formal and informal justice providers. / In partnership with the TAP Network and local civil society partners, activities were implemented in the Central African Republic and Nigeria. With capacity building training for civil society in selected countries on their strategic and thematic engagement in VNR processes (leading up to the HLPF2019 and beyond) CSPPS supported optimal civil society participation for amplifying their voice in policy processes around the VNR. Ready for Review was built around political dialogue processes taking place in context of the International Dialogue on Peacebuilding and Statebuilding (IDPS)-partnership in which CSPPS represents civil society.
Engendered peace - WPS: 40 women human rights defenders and organizations from Burundi, CAR, DRC, Rwanda, South Sudan, and Uganda convened and defined a creative common vision and agenda for feminist peacebuilding as well as collective action. Together the women peace builders assessed progress and gaps in the WPS agenda in the region, shared good practices and lessons learnt. This was followed by a press conference to disseminate the position and recommendations. SP partner WIPC partnered with Global Fund for Women to organise the meeting, which included engagement with the ICGLR Regional Training Facility, the African Union FemWise-African Network of Women Mediators, and UN Office of the Special Envoy for the Great Lakes on specific advocacy issues.
Security and access to Justice: IN NYC, a mapping was done in 2019 to analyse which INGOs and networks focus on a similar agenda on security governance and international peace operations, and specifically DRC and CAR. Based on this mapping, INGOs held meetings with targeted allies with whom we coordinated activities and messages, exchanged information and plan to collaborate in 2020.
Cordaid collaborates with ODI and IDLO, as well as other justice partners through the Pathfinders / Task Force on Justice, TAP Network, WFUNA, and other alliances relevant to SDG16.3 and the justice agenda.

OUTCOME(S): (Space for civil society): A recently established network, founded by Cordaid, IEP and CSPPS, brings together CSO's, academic institutions, think tanks and policy makers to share ongoing research and present findings of research on 'early warning early action' . A kick-off meeting took place at ISS, to be followed up by a more specific meeting after Summer. This group works in close liaison with the 'early warning early action' team from Dutch MFA. CPDE (CSO partnership for development effectiveness) has elected Cordaid as member of the Steering Committee of the CPDE, which enables CSOs to attend and contribute to the discussions of the GPEDC Steering Committee. (Security and Access to Justice): Several international NGOs engaging or interested in engaging in SJSR came together in CAR to coordinate and share information. All these NGOs were invited by the Central African coordination unit for SSR.

title.narrative: L) International development actors support inclusive development and peace and state-building processes in fragile contexts

comment.narrative:
(Civic space): We have noticed a much more positive attitude of the CDA vis-à-vis development cooperation in the last year, which is also reflected in intern party documentson this topic that feed into the program for the parliamentary elections of March 2021.
Thanks to our efforts (amongst others) support in parliament for protecting the development budget and investing extra in international covid-19 response has been strengthened tremendously. / Participation in co-organised regional exchange workshops on review and follow-up of 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and VNR processes further cement recognition of CSPPS as conduit to voice concerns of local civil society in these processes
(Engendered peace - WPS): Due to the new context created by Covid19, International Actors have increased opportunities to participate in meetings that before would not have the facilities for oversees communication. Since Cordaid and our offices are used to remote working, the programme has used the situation to increase presence.

(Q4) (Space for Civil Society): Leading on behalf of the CPDE in the GPEDC workplan work stream 1 implementation: GPEDC (Global partnership, governmental stakeholders included) has accepted to include the necessity of inclusion and multi stakeholder arrangements at country level, as two of the criteria for formulation of ToRs for in country level implementation of the Development Effectiveness agenda. / (Q2) (Space for Civil Society): Cordaid SP staff has worked directly with EC DEVCO B2 unit (CSO unit in EC), for the organisation of the EC CSO Forum. See: http: / partnershipforum2017.eu / and 2). Special session on FCAS, role of New Deal principles in FCAS, with recommendations to the EU on how EU instruments can fully support the aim of mainstreaming ND principles in implementation of national development plans. / Organized a panel on ‘supporting partnerships for sustainable peace in the CAR’, with inputs from SP partner, during the European Development Days / Organized event on Youth Peace and Security in context of HLPF2017 in partnership with UNDP and in collaboration with partners. / (Q1) (Space for Civil Society): The EC and stakeholders (CONCORD) have started preparations for the CS Forum that will take place this year in the summer on the positioning of CS in partner countries in national dialogue in their setting. Cordaid is again involved in the organisations. / IDPS translated YPS commitment into concrete action on the ground in a number of countries. Support the development of action plan to influence Burundi peace process and build coalition, with CO and partners. Support strategy paper on future of SSR in DRC with local partners in collaboration with EurAC / (Security and Access to Justice): CSPPS has agreed to participate in HL meeting on SDG realization in Fragile States

(Space for civil society): Ministers Blok and Kaag have taken up the role of religious actors as issue and it has been put on the agenda for the upcoming ambassadors' conference (end of January 2019). In a recent letter to parliament, the factor religion is described as a crucial contextual factor in many countries. / A parliamentary majority has supported the creation of a special envoy for religion in the Dutch ministry of foreign affairs. A round table will be organized in parliament in the first quarter of 2019. / VVD parlementarians asked questions during debate on the European Peace Facility based on EPLO position that was shared with foreign policy spokespersons in Dutch parliament, and they sent an e-mail with appreciation for our letter. / UN Peace Building Support Office has approved concept note on the implementation of UNSCR 2250 in Burundi, in which UNOY members collaborate on implementing the proposal. / The Council of Europe approved a parliamentary Assembly resolution for the appointment of a rapporteur who is to prepare a report of the importance of UNSC 2250 (which may lead to official endorsement by the CoE of resolution 2250). / (Security and Access to Justice): The global Task Force on Justice of the Pathfinders Initiative intends to incorporate customary and informal approaches in report to HLPF / World Justice Project will include customary and informal justice on the agenda of the 2019 World Justice Forum. / (Inclusive health services): WHO and UNFPA approached to Cordaid to finance healthcare projects related to UHC based on previous activities on UHC by Cordaid.

OUTCOME(S): (Inclusive Health): Stakeholders at universities and UN agencies disseminated an article on negotiations to achieve access for healthcare in the conflict-regions of Afghanistan featuring partner AHDS and the Cordaid global office health expert.

OUTCOME(S): Civic space: CSPPS, Namati, GPPAC, TAP Network and Saferworld co-organised a workshop during the High-level Political Forum (HLPF2019) where we showcased best practices on how civil society has been driving progress on SDG16+. In the second week of HLPF local civil society delegates from CAR, Cote d'Ivoire, Sierra Leone, Chad, Cameroon, Ghana and Timor Leste attended their respective VNR-presentations. The CSPPS network did have a two speaking slots urging for accelerated action on SDG16+, during the Thematic Review of SDG16 and during the Umbrella Event on “SDG16+ and the Future We Want” (video: https://cspps.org/media/363) / Currently, a majority in Parliament wants to increase Dutch development budget to 0.7% GDP and already make the first step to arrive there during this government. This an important positive change in comparison to past years.
Engendered peace - WPS: SP partner WIPC was invited as a technical resource at an experts meeting, which ran from 24th to 26th November and included the UNSG Special Representative on Sexual and Gender Based Violence in conflict, the Office of the UNSG Special Envoy for the Great Lakes Region, the Representative of the Chair of the AUC for the Great Lakes and Burundi, representatives from development partners and civil society networks. The meeting was follow-up of the High-level Consultation of the ICGLR Ministers of Gender and Justice in Brazzaville on the Implementation of the Kampala Declaration and the Kinshasa Communiqué. / WIPC contributed to the Uganda National Report on the Review of the Progress of Implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Platform For Action for Empowerment of Women (+25 Report) under the area of peace and inclusive societies. / UN WOMEN retained Burundi on the list as a focus country as a result of lobby and advocacy by Cordaid.
Security and access to Justice: The EU delegation and representation appreciated the call from Congolese civil society at the level of Kinshasa as well as in NYC to task with policy makers to emphasise our agenda for the exit of MONUSCO as well as prioritization of development and security support to the Congolese government. The content of the research report was discussed, which showed there is support for international support to the Congolese government and to strengthen its security apparatus.
Presentation of the finding of the Cordaid-ODI policy paper with stakeholders around everyday justice providers in relation to SDG16.3 has created opportunities for the voices of women and local communities to be heard by key policymakers at the national and global levels. Dialogues in New York, Brussels, London and Kinshasa have promoted a more nuanced and localized understanding of SDG16 implementation via focus on everyday justice providers, promoting an understanding of rule of law that is more inclusive and less state-centric. In New York PMs of Uganda and Canada co-hosted the launch event of the report, which was headlined by UN Special Rapporteur on indigenous rights. Partner organisation SALAH from Afghanistan participated in dialogue on everyday justice providers in London. In Kinshasa the DRC Minister of Justice acknowledged towards the Dutch Ambassador the importance of practical recommendations in relation to DRC's MARCs legislative framework. In Brussels bilateral presentations to EEAS (Afghanistan unit) and DG DEVCO (Afghanistan, DRC and HR units) established links between delegations of Afghanistan and DRC. The EEAS Afghanistan team will integrate report insights into forthcoming multi-annual financial framework. The presentation at EPLO prompted much debate among NGOs on how EU policy frameworks might adapt to the empirical reality of informal justice provision.
Extractives: One of the outcomes of the meeting at the OECD forum concerning the new mining code of the DRC and the interactions with international EU mechanisms for due diligence was that producing countries, such as the DRC should be more involved both in coordination mechanisms and through their civil society. As for the participation of the DRC government there has not yet been any significant advancement, but civil society has been more involved. / The EPRM (which disburses a large part of the EC accompanying measures to the EC regulation) will revise the requirement to partner with private companies for setting up consortia for tenders and has verbally agreed to open their tenders in languages other than English (Spanish and French) after this has been discussed prominently in the Brussels conference, and at the OECD meeting and in side-line discussions between EPRM representatives and DRC officials and civil society.

OUTCOME(S): (Space for civil society): As member of the Steering Committee of the CPDE (CSO partnership for development effectiveness), Cordaid has directly contributed and sharpened the content of the FCAS tailored monitoring framework which provides evidence and provided accountability by development partners on progress in implementing effective development co-operation at country, regional and global level. Through CPDE Cordaid has participated and contributed to multi stakeholder preparatory team of the High Level Session on Fragility and the adapted monitoring framework Senior Level Meeting in New York July 13th 2019 which validated the M&E Framework. Furthermore, Cordaid has directly contributed to the formulation of the Beirut Declaration and the CPDE manifesto. Both documents address shrinking space for CSOs. OECD & UNCDF has included a complete chapter on blended finance in FCAS written by Cordaid in the UNCDF / OECD report on Blending Finance in least developed countries (link: https://bit.ly/2ZcdEDs). In the report Cordaid has been acknowledged as a leading organization on the topic of fragility. The Dutch MFA is supporting and co-sponsoring Cordaid in the launch of the Report on Blending Finance in least developed countries during the HLPF in New York, which will take place on 15th July.
(Security and Access to Justice): EU policy makers again emphasised they do not support a hasty departure of MONUSCO, but a more phased and balanced changing mandate of MONUSCO. Also, within their range of options, they committed to investement in the Justice Sector and the will to look into Security Sector Reform. MoFA indicated that NL is most likely willing to support the EU reengagement in the justice sector (blocked by MSs) The essential role of customary and informal justice in ensuring justice for all by 2030 was acknowledged in several key international fora, ensuring this issue will be on the agenda at HLPF and the SDG Summit. Cordaid pushed the topic on the agendas of the World Justice Forum (at which Cordaid and ODI co-hosted an Expert Group Meeting and public dialogue, featuring Cordaid Afghanistan expertise) and high-level SDG16 Conference (at which Cordaid participated in an IDLO-hosted panel alongside justice ministers and senior human rights activists).

Furthermore, Cordaid has directly contributed to the formulation of the Beirut Declaration and the CPDE manifesto. Both documents address shrinking space for CSOs. OECD & UNCDF has included a complete chapter on blended finance in FCAS written by Cordaid in the UNCDF / OECD report on Blending Finance in least developed countries (link: https://bit.ly/2ZcdEDs). In the report Cordaid has been acknowledged as a leading organization on the topic of fragility. The Dutch MFA is supporting and co-sponsoring Cordaid in the launch of the Report on Blending Finance in least developed countries during the HLPF in New York, which will take place on 15th July.

title.narrative: (SP) Number of Cordaid partners present on international stage as experts and case providers

comment.narrative: (Engendered Peace - YPS): UNOY has been able to propose several of their members to speak to the UNSC e.g. from South Sudan Gatwal Augustine Gatkuoth Yul gave a powerful speech and their Yemeni member Olla Al Sakkaf spoke on the impact of COVID19 crisis on 27th of April in war-torn Yemen: her speech was shared on social media on the covid 19 crisis https://www.facebook.com/UNYouthEnvoy/videos/2986193131463842 / (Health): UHC in DRC and video Devex

CSO recommendations incorporated in Afghan National Development and Peace Framework II in run-up to Geneva Conference / UNSCR 2535 was adapted based on reporting / shadow resolution from the youth consultations organized by UNOY with Cordaid partners.

(Space for civil society): Workshops on shrinking civic space in all SP countries / Civic Space workshop in Afghanistan (co-facilitated by Cordaid and CSPPS) / (Engendered peace- YPS): In the first half of 2019, Cordaid with two local partners launched the youth, peace building program in Burundi. 144 youth leaders are selected from 6 provinces. In view of localizing UN Resolution 2250 Cordaid works together with two partners, members of the UNOY network to strengthen the role of youth to contribute to peace and community security (with specific attention for the daily safety of women). / (Inclusive Health): trainings
Discussions around spotlight report / Cordaid YPS L&A to partner countries, research network UNOY, YPS L&A from UNOY to their members
e-learning about lobbying at the EU / On UHC with KIT in Kinshasa. / RBF S&J training for staff and partners.

(Civic space): CS considerations take on board in joint IDPS statement on COVID-19
(Space for civil society): New Peace Vision document IDPS

As a result of the Building Change campaign, of which Cordaid is part, Dutch government agreed to check every new law on consequences for developing countries (policy coherence for development). Buidling Change refers to this as the 'SDG check'. / Minister Kaag (in her position as co-chair of the taskforce on Justice she focuses on SDG 16.3, access to justice) has stated during the budget discussions in Dutch parliament that for her SDG 16 is the most important SDG. Since for Cordaid's SP also SDG 16 is key, this provideds a lot of momentum in 2019, when The Netherlands will organize a number of justice events.
Key justice stakeholders (Pathfinders, IDLO, ICJ) agree to participate in WG on Customary and Informal Justice and SDG16+ / UNSCR 2535
Key justice stakeholders (Pathfinders, IDLO, ICJ) agree to participate in WG on Customary and Informal Justice and SDG16+ / UNSCR 2535

comment.narrative: Total score for the SP program (Capacitating Change: restoring the social contract in Fragile Contexts). Each CSO is only counted once in the total. CSOs with increased capacity are NOT added again if they were already counted in previous years to avoid double counting. title.narrative: K) National decision makers initiate policy processes with inclusive civil society engagement

comment.narrative: (Engendered peace - WPS): The Ministry of Peace in Afghanistan asked for input on the needs of CSOs to be involved in the peace process.

(Inclusive health services): Following a training by Cordaid on advocacy and negotiations for Afghan Ministry of Health, the Ministry and Cordaid organised a workshop on UHC in 2018 and are currently preparing a symposium on health financing for February 2019. The Minister of Public Health in Afghanistan, Mr. Feroz, stressed the importance of UHC in an published interview and spoke highly of Cordaids work for UHC at several public events.

OUTCOME(S): Engendered peace - WPS: “After the 1996-2001 oppressive Taliban rule, the women of Afghanistan came out of the dark. We will never go back.” Women in Afghanistan have every right to be represented equally in the ongoing peace process between the Afghan government, the United States, and the Taliban. Women’s inclusion should be a non-negotiable priority, especially as the peace talks will determine the future of Afghanistan for decades to come. Yet women’s voices have barely been heard. As part of its Strategic Partnership efforts, Cordaid and its Afghan partner AWN have worked to enable and empower women in Afghanistan to claim a seat at the table. Cordaid and AWN took their struggle to the United Nations in 2019, addressing the UN Security Council to remind them of the central role that women have always played in the development of post-Taliban Afghanistan. A meeting with US Senator Jeanne Shaheen saw her demand Secretary of State Mike Pompeo for women to be included in the peace negotiations. Eventually, the United States mandated that women should be structurally involved at the Doha talks should be Afghan women. Cordaid and AWN will support a small delegation to participate in future peace talks, ensuring they represent voices that will otherwise not be heard – those of women in Afghanistan, from the provinces to the cities. (https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/2953/text?r=10&s=1)
Inclusive Health services: At the request of the President's Office and the Ministry of Health of DRC Cordaid, local CSOs, WHO and World Bank assisted the MoH and the President's Office to draft a national strategy to achieve Universal Health Coverage for DRC.

OUTCOME(S): (Space for civil society): The Cordaid experience with the situation in Burundi was presented as a good example of strong engagement by Dutch MFA and the embassy in Bujumbura in a meeting of the BMO delegation with minister Blok on the topic of shrinking space for civil society organizations. A similar meeting took also place with minister Kaag, which shows the great interest by the Ministry for the topic space of CSOs.
The CSPPS initiated Ready for Review project has been set up in consultation other IDPS stakeholder representatives - and has created space for engagement and involvement of in process of reporting on progress made in localization and implementation of the 2030 Agenda in national contexts (CAR, Cote d'Ivoire, Chad, Sierra Leone, Timor Leste, Rwanda and Nigeria)

title.narrative: J) Stakeholders support the role of civil society and assure that the voice of communities and minority groups are heard in policy dialogue

comment.narrative:
(Engendered peace - YPS): Security Council member states Domenican Republic and France have invited UNOY to organize a youth consultatiion with their members to negiotate a new UN resolution on YPS.
(Engendered peace - WPS): UN WOMEN invited 3 civil society briefers from Afghanistan, South Sudan and CAR for an informal meeting to provide direct input towards Security Council members on the respective countries.

(Engendered peace - YPS): Security Council member states Domenican Republic and France have invited UNOY to organize a youth consultatiion with their members to negiotate a new UN resolution on YPS.
(Engendered peace - WPS): UN WOMEN invited 3 civil society briefers from Afghanistan, South Sudan and CAR for an informal meeting to provide direct input towards Security Council members on the respective countries.

(Space for civil society): The French MFA is supporting civil society engagement in the preparation of VNR reports (voluntary national review, process of review of implementation of 2030 Agenda in given country context) in FCAS. The French MFA will bring CS actors up to speed on how they can meaningfully engage and participate in process as partner in context of HLPF2019 SDG16 review and will coordinate action to ensure inclusive and participatory reporting process in FCAS-countries. / OECD International Network on Conflict and Fragility (INCAF) has included concerns raised by CSPPS over shrinking space for civil society in their communique. / Dutch MOFA (by direct instruction of minister Kaag), officially supports the course of action agreed upon in the Burundi Platform+ meeting, which includes commitment to support INGOs active in Burundi. The action points are aimed at respecting human rights in Burundi related to the Burundi INGO suspension. / Dutch parlamentarians Ploumen, van Oijk en Karabulut - on our instigation - asked questions to the Minister of foreign affairs Stef Blok on the "The Hague Youth Declaration on Human Rights in Action". This is an actionable agenda based on the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which was adopted 70 years ago. / The High Commission on Human Rights has invited Kompass and Cordaid to visit Geneva to strategize on collaboration on the actionable agenda of the The Hague Youth Declaration. / EU has adopted the Council conclusions on the role of young people in building a secure and cohesive society following inputs by the EU- Young Advocacy Team.

(Space for civil society): The French MFA is supporting civil society engagement in the preparation of VNR reports (voluntary national review, process of review of implementation of 2030 Agenda in given country context) in FCAS. The French MFA will bring CS actors up to speed on how they can meaningfully engage and participate in process as partner in context of HLPF2019 SDG16 review and will coordinate action to ensure inclusive and participatory reporting process in FCAS-countries. / OECD International Network on Conflict and Fragility (INCAF) has included concerns raised by CSPPS over shrinking space for civil society in their communique. / Dutch MOFA (by direct instruction of minister Kaag), officially supports the course of action agreed upon in the Burundi Platform+ meeting, which includes commitment to support INGOs active in Burundi. The action points are aimed at respecting human rights in Burundi related to the Burundi INGO suspension. / Dutch parlamentarians Ploumen, van Oijk en Karabulut - on our instigation - asked questions to the Minister of foreign affairs Stef Blok on the "The Hague Youth Declaration on Human Rights in Action". This is an actionable agenda based on the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which was adopted 70 years ago. / The High Commission on Human Rights has invited Kompass and Cordaid to visit Geneva to strategize on collaboration on the actionable agenda of the The Hague Youth Declaration. / EU has adopted the Council conclusions on the role of young people in building a secure and cohesive society following inputs by the EU- Young Advocacy Team.

OUTCOME(S): Civic space: The political and policy interest in the nexus between religion, peace and security is keeping a lot of momentum in The Netherlands, with (apart from CDA, CU) also D66 taking an active interest with the tabling of an initiative bill to also pay attention to people that are not or no longer religious.
Engendered peace - YPS: EU member state Finland announced the development of National Action Plan on youth, peace and security through a participatory process Finland's 2250 network gathering the inputs of young people and civil society, this as a result of different lobby and advocacy efforts amongst others from UNOY. Finland presented this commitment during the launch event organized by UNOY (the United Network of Young Peace builders), EPLO, Search for Common Ground, and Cordaid on the report "mapping the progress of youth, peace and security in the EU".
Security and access to Justice: The US permanent mission to the UN facilitated the visit of a local partner who was not able to get a visa. She was able to travel and speak in a panel together with the SRSG of MONUSCO.
Inclusive Health services: The Ministry of Health in DRC has used a study by the School of Public Health of the University of Kinshasa to ask communities the pros and cons of Community Health Insurances or Mutuelles de Sante , which Cordaid commissioned, as input for the design of the national strategy on UHC in DRC.

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered peace): In October 2020 during the anniversary of UNSCR 1325, Cordaid, UNOY peace builders, CSPPS and 4 youth led organizations from Afghanistan, Libya, Iraq and Yemen organized a side-event on youth-led activism on women, peace and security addressing the intersection on both agenda’s and providing recommendations. The event was attended by policy decision makers, INGOs and national civil society.
(Security and Access to Justice): Key justice actors like Pathfinders, donors (inc. NL), and relevant UN agencies engaging with civil society-generated findings on practical options for transitional justice in highly fragile contexts like CAR, with policy implications for the most fragile contexts more broadly.
(Inclusive Health): Dutch MoFa requested Cordaid health expert to present the opportunities for more and better healthcare in Afghanistan in case of a (preliminary) peace deal between the Government of Afghanistan and Taliban.
(Civic Space): The Afghanistan Platform, chaired by Cordaid, took the initiative to organize an international expert meeting in the context of the upcoming Geneva donor conference. The meeting was very well received by Dutch MFA. Both the new Ambassador and the Director Stability and Humanitarian Assistance actively participated. The report of the meeting will feed into the broader CSO input for the Geneva conference and will also be part of the synthesis document BAAG (British & Irish Afghanistan umbrella) is producing for Geneva.

OUTCOME(S): (Space for civil society): The trajectory on 'religion in the Dutch foreign policy', which came high on the policy and political agenda in The Hague thanks to a strong push by a coalition of Cordaid, Mensen met een Missie, Pax and Prisma, had a peak in the form of an international conference and public event. Our South Sudanese partner Josephine Chandiru Drama, director of Stewardwomen, spoke both during the expert meeting and the public event. As a result of the coalition's advocacy, a special envoy on religious freedom will be installed, and the topic religion is integrated into the training of officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Civil Society partners have contributed to the Rome Civil Society Declaration on SDG16+, which was coordinated by CSPPS. The Civil Society Declaration is seen as the counterpart of the member states declaration in the making ahead of the SDG Summit in September - relevant therein is also the commitment part where CS states indicate what they intend to do as part of their commitment and parternship for accelerated action on 2030 Agenda and SDG16+ in particular. (Engendered Peace (YPS and WPS)): Qatar, co-hosted the first global conversation on youth participation in peace processes in Helsinki which was also co-organized by SP partner UNOY. The member state has pledged during this event to host a follow-up Symposium in Doha in 2020 to reflect on piloting of recommendations in specific countries (including member states looking into the developments of a National Action Plan on the implementation of UNSCR2250). Members of SP Partner UNOY represents and secures the youth voice in the engagement with member states and UN agencies.

title.narrative: E) Communities organize inclusive dialogue in which women, youth and minority groups can voice their needs and concerns

comment.narrative: OUTCOME(S): Security and access to Justice: In 2 communities, focus group discussions were organise to validate the data coming out of the street interviews, to better understand them but also to give community representatives the opportunity to correct them.

title.narrative: C) CSOs and Cordaid increase community awareness on advocacy topics

comment.narrative:
OUTCOME(S): Engendered peace - YPS: The Cordaid website was frequently visited during the exhibition in the Municipality of the Hague showing the other face of youth leaders in conflict who are contributors to positive change. The exhibition provides information on the UN resolution 2250, the shrinking civic space of youth and the risks they encounter, with stories from youth leaders from Afghanistan, Libya and Iraq 27 November - 13 December 2019.
Security and access to Justice: In all zones in CAR and DRC were Cordaid and partners did data collection for a research project with SIPRI, restitution sessions were organised on the outcomes of the research and the recommendations which were based on this by the local partners (8 sessions by 2 partners).

OUTCOME(S): Engendered peace - YPS: The Cordaid website was frequently visited during the exhibition in the Municipality of the Hague showing the other face of youth leaders in conflict who are contributors to positive change. The exhibition provides information on the UN resolution 2250, the shrinking civic space of youth and the risks they encounter, with stories from youth leaders from Afghanistan, Libya and Iraq 27 November - 13 December 2019.
Security and access to Justice: In all zones in CAR and DRC were Cordaid and partners did data collection for a research project with SIPRI, restitution sessions were organised on the outcomes of the research and the recommendations which were based on this by the local partners (8 sessions by 2 partners).

OUTCOME(S): (Engendered Peace (YPS and WPS)): in cooperation with two youth organizations (members of UNOY) a youth, peace and security program on localizing UN Resolution 2250 in Burundi has been launched with support from the SP program and the UNPBF program. The program engages 144 youth leaders from 6 provinces. The program focuses on strengthening the role of youth to contribute to peace and community security (with specific attention for the daily safety of women).

title.narrative: F) Communities increase their capacity for advocacy towards decision makers
0) Partners in the SP (Cordaid, MoFA, Embassies, Local CSOs) improve working relationships and coordinate L&A interventions

comment.narrative:
OUTCOME(S): Civic space: Meeting with MFA staff in context of the KPSRL Conference confirmed interest to align and accelerate work on localisation of SDG16 Agenda in countries of mutual interest. Discussion will see follow-up in Q1-2020.
Engendered peace - WPS: Deputy permanent representative Frederique de Man in NY at the Dutch permanent representation towards the United Nations committed to increased involvement of the Dutch government in the Afghan Peace process and the role of women. / Dutch embassy in Juba are very interested the outcomes of the Barometer report as it made clear that the government of South Sudan is spreading incorrect information about the amount of sexual violence. Embassy was very supportive of our work and encouraged us to share findings with SC council members. / AWN and Cordaid developed a shared strategy on international lobby and go on lobby and advocacy trips and maintain this relationship during various international events such as 1325 anniversary and CSW.
Security and access to Justice: Through the research project with SIPRI "Security and Justice in CAR and the DRC: International Aims, Local Expectations", relations were created in 3 countries: USA (NYC-UN), CAR and DRC and maintained with key stakeholders (governments, international CSOs and embassies/Permanent Missions. Activities were organised in NYC (NGO briefing) to coordinate advocacy towards international stakeholders with other NGOs and networks.
Presentation of the everyday justice research (Cordaid-ODI report on customary and informal justice) has strengthened relations with NL embassy in Kinshasa; and facilitated strong coordination between Cordaid and partner CSOs in Afghanistan and DRC.
Inclusive Health services: Cordaid joined the delegation of DRC to attend the High Level Meeting on Universal Health Coverage in New York during the UN General Assembly. Cordaid coordinated this with the Dutch embassy in DRC, the Dutch delegation in New York and the MOFA in The Hague.

title.narrative: (SP) Number of jointly formulated strategies
